Award.AwardTitle: Atomistic Studies of Concentrated Multicomponent Nickel-Based Alloys Utilizing Atom-Probe Tomography and Vacancy-Mediated Lattice Kinetic Monte Carlo Simulations
Award.AbstractNarration:
Non-Technical Abstract

This research program is focused on how phase separation occurs in nickel-aluminum based alloys, which are the physical bases of all nickel-based superalloys and which may contain up to 12 different alloying elements, with each element serving a particular purpose. Nickel-based superalloys are utilized for turbine blades and disks, which are at the heart of both military and commercial jet engines as well as natural gas-fired turbine engines that produce electricity, and which operate at extremely elevated temperatures. To study these materials at an atomic scale in this technologically important class of alloys, extensive utilization will be made of the Northwestern University Center for Atom-Probe Tomography. Atom-Probe Tomography is a unique technique that allows characterizing materials at the sub-nano to nanoscale. Applying this technique to nickel-aluminum based alloys will allow understanding the development of the final microstructure, which is of great significance and technological importance for controlling the physical and mechanical properties of a material at microscopic and macroscopic length scales. This work will help train the next generation of materials scientists in this state of the art technique.


Technical Abstract

The kinetic pathways in the different stages of alloy phase separation (nucleation, growth and coarsening) of concentrated multicomponent nickel-based supersaturated solid-solutions are critical for understanding the development of the final microstructure, which is of great significance and technological importance for controlling the physical and mechanical properties of a material at microscopic and macroscopic length scales. To study the temporal evolution of phase separation, the PI will perform correlative experiments utilizing ultraviolet laser-assisted atom-probe tomography (APT) and vacancy-mediated lattice-kinetic Monte Carlo (LKMC) simulations, which permit understanding this evolution on an atomic scale. This work will also employ microhardness measurements and transmission electron microscopy experiments. The temporal evolution is studied starting with the clustering of atoms to form embryos exhibiting short-range order (SRO), which are the precursors of stable nuclei (precipitates); thus, allowing study of SRO and then precipitates with long-range order (LRO) and observation of growth and coarsening. All of the 10 plus physical parameters, for describing the temporal evolution, are measured via APT and simulated via LKMC simulations. Additionally, the PI will study the evolution during the quasi-steady coarsening regime and compare these results with the Philippe-Voorhees (P-V) mean-field modeling of multicomponent alloys (2013) for selected ternary and quaternary nickel-based alloys, which involves the use of both thermodynamic and mobility data bases. This will yield a realistic approach to quasi-stationary coarsening of a polydispersed distribution of precipitates embedded in a matrix. This multipronged experimental and simulation approach yields information at the atomic scale through the continuum length scale.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Ni-based superalloys are widely used in high-temperature aerospace jet engines and land-based gas turbine engines due to their superior strength, coarsening, creep, corrosion, and oxidation resistance at elevated temperatures. The microstructures of high-strength Ni-based superalloys consist of coherent ordered γ?(L12)-precipitates in a disordered nickel-rich γ(f.c.c.)-matrix. The coarsening of γ?(L12)-precipitates in a nickel-rich γ(f.c.c.)-matrix play a crucial role in the development and stability of microstructures of alloys, which are required for use at elevated temperatures for extended periods of time. The driving force for the coarsening process is the minimization of the overall interfacial energy of the system under conditions where the volume fractions of the phases are nearly at equilibrium values. From the atomistic studies of concentrated multicomponent nickel-based alloys, we have four major outcomes as following.

First, the morphological evolution of γ?(L12)-precipitates in Ni-Al-Cr alloys as well as their compositional evolution as a function of aging time at 873 K are studied theoretically to understand the mechanism and its effects on the morphological changes by employing the density functional theory (DFT) first-principles calculations, based on atom-probe tomography (APT) studiess. The DFT calculations yield physically meaningful values of the interfacial free energies of the {100}, {110} and {111} heterophase interfaces, accounting for the first time the effects of temperature on the coherency strain-energy and phonon vibrational entropy. The results were published as ?Atomistic studies of concentrated multicomponent nickel-based alloys utilizing atom-probe tomography and vacancy-mediated lattice kinetic monte carlo simulations? Acta Materialia  (2019).

Second, we studied the roles of refractory elements (R= Re, W) systematically on the temporal evolution of the nanostructure and chemistry in a model ternary Ni-10.0Al-8.5Cr at.% superalloy. The effects of W and Re are assessed by studying the temporal evolution of changes in the nanostructures of the γ'(L12)-precipitates, the phases?s compositions, the concentration profiles, the partitioning ratios of the constituent elements, the absolute values of the interfacial compositional widths between γ(f.c.c.)/γ'(L12) phases and the microhardness as the alloy ages at 1073 K with aging times to 256 h. The results were published as ?Effects of tungsten and rhenium additions on phase-separation in a model Ni-Al-Cr-W-Re superalloy: A four-dimensional study,? in J. Alloy Compound  (2019).

Third, the process of phase separation in Ni-6.5Al-9.9Mo at.% has been investigated by APT and lattice-kinetic Monte Carlo (LKMC) simulations. The addition of Mo to the binary Ni-Al system reduces the lattice misfit between the γ'(L12)-Ni3(AlxMo1-x)-precipitates and the γ(f.c.c.)-matrix, leading to misfit-free γ'(L12)-precipitates. Both 3-D APT and LKMC results demonstrate that the interfacial compositional width, δi(t), and δi(t)/ values decrease with increasing <R(t)> values. The δi(t) are measured to be 1.89?0.22, 2.09?0.12, and 2.64?0.03 nm for Ni, Al, and Mo, respectively, and the interfacial free energy is determined to be 19.9 mJ m-2, for TCNi7 database, and 24.7 mJ m-2 for LKMC simulations. This result was submitted to Acta materialia under the title ?Morphological, nanostructural,and compositional evolution during phase separation of a model Ni-Al-Mo superalloy: APT experiments and LKMC simulations,?  which is now under review.

            Finally, we studied the diffusion coupling effect on the interfacial free energy and compositional trajectories during phase-separation in a quaternary Ni-Al-Cr-Re superalloy. The local equilibrium concentrations across the γ(f.c.c.)/γ′(L12) interfaces are represented in a quaternary phase-diagram, employing a tetrahedron, and compared with the Philippe-Voorhees (PV) coarsening model in the stationary coarsening regime. The calculated interfacial free energies (17.6 ? 5.4) mJ/m2 at 973 K, for the γ(f.c.c.)/γ′(L12) interfaces, including the mobility tensor in the PV model. This result was published in arXiv under the title ?An Atom-Probe Tomographic Study of the Compositional Trajectories During γ(f.c.c.)/γ′(L12) Phase-Separation in a Ni-Al-Cr-Re Superalloy?, which will be submitted to Acta Materialia.

The instrument used in this research, APT, has a significant impact on the field of materials characterization and development as it is capable of the compositional measurement for both 3D imaging and atomic-scale (0.1-0.3nm resolution in-depth and 0.3-0.5nm laterally). The results of APT and computation simulation studies, DFT and LKMC, suggested a new method for the recent Fermi National Accelerator Laboratory (FNAL) collaboration project for high-performance superconducting radio frequency cavity applications and Co-based superalloy research. The experimental approach we are deveoping has also been emulated by other groups around the world. The techniques we have developed for APT are relevant for other fields of material science: thin-film reactions; interfacial segregation; chemical changes due to radiation damage; magnetic tunnel junctions; organic/inorganic interfaces, etc. We also provide instrument access, know-how, technical support, and analytical services to researchers from academia, National Labs and industry, in the US and internationally through the Northwestern University Center for Atom-Probe Tomography (NUCAPT) facility. The current research efforts of modeled Ni-based alloy over many years have been also beneficial to the education of high school, undergraduate, M.S., Ph.D., postdoctoral students, professional researchers, and under-represented minority and women students via outreach and workshop style training units.

 


Last Modified: 11/05/2020
Modified by: David N Seidman
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Ni-based superalloys are widely used in high-temperature aerospace jet engines and land-based gas turbine engines due to their superior strength, coarsening, creep, corrosion, and oxidation resistance at elevated temperatures. The microstructures of high-strength Ni-based superalloys consist of coherent ordered γ?(L12)-precipitates in a disordered nickel-rich γ(f.c.c.)-matrix. The coarsening of γ?(L12)-precipitates in a nickel-rich γ(f.c.c.)-matrix play a crucial role in the development and stability of microstructures of alloys, which are required for use at elevated temperatures for extended periods of time. The driving force for the coarsening process is the minimization of the overall interfacial energy of the system under conditions where the volume fractions of the phases are nearly at equilibrium values. From the atomistic studies of concentrated multicomponent nickel-based alloys, we have four major outcomes as following. First, the morphological evolution of γ?(L12)-precipitates in Ni-Al-Cr alloys as well as their compositional evolution as a function of aging time at 873 K are studied theoretically to understand the mechanism and its effects on the morphological changes by employing the density functional theory (DFT) first-principles calculations, based on atom-probe tomography (APT) studiess. The DFT calculations yield physically meaningful values of the interfacial free energies of the {100}, {110} and {111} heterophase interfaces, accounting for the first time the effects of temperature on the coherency strain-energy and phonon vibrational entropy. The results were published as ?Atomistic studies of concentrated multicomponent nickel-based alloys utilizing atom-probe tomography and vacancy-mediated lattice kinetic monte carlo simulations? Acta Materialia (2019). Second, we studied the roles of refractory elements (R= Re, W) systematically on the temporal evolution of the nanostructure and chemistry in a model ternary Ni-10.0Al-8.5Cr at.% superalloy. The effects of W and Re are assessed by studying the temporal evolution of changes in the nanostructures of the γ'(L12)-precipitates, the phases?s compositions, the concentration profiles, the partitioning ratios of the constituent elements, the absolute values of the interfacial compositional widths between γ(f.c.c.)/γ'(L12) phases and the microhardness as the alloy ages at 1073 K with aging times to 256 h. The results were published as ?Effects of tungsten and rhenium additions on phase-separation in a model Ni-Al-Cr-W-Re superalloy: A four-dimensional study,? in J. Alloy Compound (2019). Third, the process of phase separation in Ni-6.5Al-9.9Mo at.% has been investigated by APT and lattice-kinetic Monte Carlo (LKMC) simulations. The addition of Mo to the binary Ni-Al system reduces the lattice misfit between the γ'(L12)-Ni3(AlxMo1-x)-precipitates and the γ(f.c.c.)-matrix, leading to misfit-free γ'(L12)-precipitates. Both 3-D APT and LKMC results demonstrate that the interfacial compositional width, δi(t), and δi(t)/ values decrease with increasing <R(t)> values. The δi(t) are measured to be 1.89?0.22, 2.09?0.12, and 2.64?0.03 nm for Ni, Al, and Mo, respectively, and the interfacial free energy is determined to be 19.9 mJ m-2, for TCNi7 database, and 24.7 mJ m-2 for LKMC simulations. This result was submitted to Acta materialia under the title ?Morphological, nanostructural,and compositional evolution during phase separation of a model Ni-Al-Mo superalloy: APT experiments and LKMC simulations,? which is now under review. Finally, we studied the diffusion coupling effect on the interfacial free energy and compositional trajectories during phase-separation in a quaternary Ni-Al-Cr-Re superalloy. The local equilibrium concentrations across the γ(f.c.c.)/γ′(L12) interfaces are represented in a quaternary phase-diagram, employing a tetrahedron, and compared with the Philippe-Voorhees (PV) coarsening model in the stationary coarsening regime. The calculated interfacial free energies (17.6 ? 5.4) mJ/m2 at 973 K, for the γ(f.c.c.)/γ′(L12) interfaces, including the mobility tensor in the PV model. This result was published in arXiv under the title ?An Atom-Probe Tomographic Study of the Compositional Trajectories During γ(f.c.c.)/γ′(L12) Phase-Separation in a Ni-Al-Cr-Re Superalloy?, which will be submitted to Acta Materialia. The instrument used in this research, APT, has a significant impact on the field of materials characterization and development as it is capable of the compositional measurement for both 3D imaging and atomic-scale (0.1-0.3nm resolution in-depth and 0.3-0.5nm laterally). The results of APT and computation simulation studies, DFT and LKMC, suggested a new method for the recent Fermi National Accelerator Laboratory (FNAL) collaboration project for high-performance superconducting radio frequency cavity applications and Co-based superalloy research. The experimental approach we are deveoping has also been emulated by other groups around the world. The techniques we have developed for APT are relevant for other fields of material science: thin-film reactions; interfacial segregation; chemical changes due to radiation damage; magnetic tunnel junctions; organic/inorganic interfaces, etc. We also provide instrument access, know-how, technical support, and analytical services to researchers from academia, National Labs and industry, in the US and internationally through the Northwestern University Center for Atom-Probe Tomography (NUCAPT) facility. The current research efforts of modeled Ni-based alloy over many years have been also beneficial to the education of high school, undergraduate, M.S., Ph.D., postdoctoral students, professional researchers, and under-represented minority and women students via outreach and workshop style training units.
